title: Using fma: worked examples
text: package contains collection datasets designed accompany textbook “Forecasting: Methods Applications” Makridakis, Wheelwright & Hyndman (Wiley, 3rd ed., 1998). book can purchased .  fma package loaded, forecast package also loaded, providing functions fit models compute forecasts. vignette give brief introduction ways datasets fma package can analysed using forecast package. figures Chapter 2 reproduced . figure numbers used correspond figures textbook.

title: Using fma: worked examples
text: number data sets included fma package, referenced examples throughout book. Descriptions data sets used vignette included : auto Cross-sectional data 45 automobiles Consumer Reports, April 1990, pp. 235-255. Columns: Model: name automobile Country: country origin automobile Mileage: mileage automobile (miles per gallon) Price: price car ($US) beer Monthly time series data Australian beer production (megalitres) January 1991 August 1995. elec Monthly time series data Australian electricity production January 1956 August 1995 kWh. milk Monthly time series data milk production per cow (pounds) 14 year time period.

title: Using fma: worked examples
text: single important thing first exploring data visualize graphs. basic features data, including patterns unusual observations, easily seen graphs. Sometimes graphs also suggest possible explanations variation data. Chapter 2 describes three main types graph useful forecasting. R code can used reproduce examples shown .

what: Time plots and time series patterns
title: Using fma: worked examples
text: time series data obvious graphical form time plot (data plotted time). time plot immediately reveals trends time, regular seasonal behavior, systematic features data. Figure 2-1 shows time plot beer data. reveals range data time peaks occur, relative size peaks randomness time series.
code: beer %>%   autoplot() +   ggtitle("Monthly Australian Beer Production") +   xlab("Year") +   ylab("Megalitres") +   labs(caption = "Figure 2-1: Time plot of monthly Australian beer production (megaliters, Ml) from January 1991–August 1995.")

title: Using fma: worked examples
text: time series data seasonal patterns, often useful also produce seasonal plot. consists data plotted individuals “seasons” data observed. something like time plot except data season overlapped. seasonal plot enables underlying seasonal pattern obvious, well easily identify deviations pattern. Figure 2-2 shows seasonal plot beer data. can done using ggseasonplot() function forecast package:
code: ggseasonplot(beer, col = rainbow(5), year.labels = TRUE) +   ggtitle('Monthly Australian Beer Production') +   xlab('Months') + ylab('Megalitres') +   labs(caption = 'Figure 2-2: A seasonal plot of the Australian beer production data. Note that production peaks in     November and December in preparation for the southern hemisphere summer and is least in winter.') #> Warning in fortify(data, ...): Arguments in `...` must be used. #> ✖ Problematic argument: #> • na.rm = TRUE #> ℹ Did you misspell an argument name?

title: Using fma: worked examples
text: Time plots seasonal plots appropriate cross-sectional data. Patterns data can readily visualised scatterplots. Scatterplots help visualise relationships variables interest data set. Figure 2-3 shows plot two variables auto data set.  auto data also additional explanatory variable Country. categorical variable plotted Price way continuous Mileage variable. However, can include Country information scatterplot shape aesthetic. displayed Figure 2-4 .
code: auto %>%   ggplot(aes(x = Mileage, y = Price)) +   geom_point() +   xlab("Mileage (mpg)") + ylab("Price ($US)") +   ggtitle("Price/Mileage Relationship for 45 Automobiles") +   labs(caption = 'Figure 2-3: A scatterplot of price versus mileage for the automobile data.') auto %>%   ggplot(aes(x = Mileage, y = Price, shape=Country)) +   geom_point(size=2) +   xlab("Mileage (mpg)") + ylab("Price ($US)") +   ggtitle("Price/Mileage Relationship for 45 Automobiles") +   labs(caption = 'Figure 2-4: A scatterplot showing price, mileage, and the country of origin for the automobile data.')

title: Using fma: worked examples
text: addition graphics, also helpful provide numerical summaries. summary number data set called statistic.

title: Using fma: worked examples
text: Table 2-4 shows computation useful univariate statistics Mileage variable auto dataset, filtering data set include cars Japan. statistics defined explained textbook. following code produces summary statistics: Table 2-4
code: auto_japan <- auto %>%   filter(Country == 'Japan') auto_japan #>                            Model Country Mileage Price #> 6                   Mazda MPV V6   Japan      19 14944 #> 7                   Nissan Van 4   Japan      19 14799 #> 9                Acura Legend V6   Japan      20 24760 #> 11            Mitsubishi Wagon 4   Japan      20 14929 #> 12               Nissan Axxess 4   Japan      20 13949 #> 13           Mitsubishi Sigma V6   Japan      21 17879 #> 14               Nissan Stanza 4   Japan      21 11650 #> 16                  Mazda 929 V6   Japan      21 23300 #> 23              Nissan Maxima V6   Japan      22 17899 #> 27             Toyota Cressida 6   Japan      23 21498 #> 29                Nissan 240SX 4   Japan      24 13249 #> 31               Subaru Loyale 4   Japan      25  9599 #> 33           Mitsubishi Galant 4   Japan      25 10989 #> 37        Honda Prelude Si 4WS 4   Japan      27 13945 #> 38                   Subaru XT 4   Japan      28 13071 #> 40               Mazda Protege 4   Japan      32  6599 #> 43          Honda Civic CRX Si 4   Japan      33  9410 #> 44                Subaru Justy 3   Japan      34  5866 #> 45               Toyota Tercel 4   Japan      35  6488 auto_japan %>%   summarise(mean = mean(Mileage),             median= median(Mileage),             MAD = sum(abs(Mileage - mean(Mileage)))/n(),             MSD = sum((Mileage - mean(Mileage))^2)/n(),             Variance = var(Mileage),             Std_Dev = sd(Mileage)) #>       mean median      MAD      MSD Variance  Std_Dev #> 1 24.68421     23 4.371191 27.05817  28.5614 5.344287

title: Using fma: worked examples
text: section introduces concepts covariance, correlation auto-correlation. Table 2-6 shows calculation bivariate statistics auto data Country == "Japan" (data used Table 2-5). variables considered Price Mileage. section units Price converted thousands dollars. Calculation statistics given : Table 2-6
code: auto_japan %>%   mutate(Price = Price/1000) %>%   summarise(mean_milage = mean(Mileage),             mean_price = mean(Price),             sd_mileage = sd(Mileage),             sd_price = sd(Price),             covariance = cov(Price, Mileage),             correlation = cor(Price, Mileage)) #>   mean_milage mean_price sd_mileage sd_price covariance correlation #> 1    24.68421   13.93805   5.344287 5.400006  -21.00154  -0.7277246

title: Using fma: worked examples
text: covariance correlation coefficient statistics measure extent linear relationship two variables can used identify explanatory relationships. Autocovariance autocorrelation comparable measures serve purpose single time series. example, compare YtY_t (observation time tt) Yt−1Y_{t−1} (observation time t−1t−1), see consecutive observations related. observation Yt−1Y_{t−1} described lagged one period. Together autocorrelations lags 1, 2, …, make autocorrelation function ACF. much easier understand autocorrelations plotting lag. plot known correlogram. Figure 2-6 shows ACF beer data:
code: ggAcf(beer) +   ggtitle('ACF of Beer Production') +   labs(caption = 'Figure 2-6: The correlogram (or ACF plot) for the beer production data.')

title: Using fma: worked examples
text: section book, variety measures forecasting (modelling) accuracy defined. Functions forecast package can used calculate accuracy measures. textbook refers simple forecasting method called Naive Forecast 1 (NF1) used benchmark compare sophisticated methods. method uses recent observation available forecast. Table 2-11 shows NF1 used forecast monthly beer production year 1995. can helpful look autocorrelations forecast errors. Figure 2.7 shows forecast errors obtained applying NF1 method Australia monthly beer data.
code: window(beer, start=c(1994,12)) %>%   naive() %>%   accuracy() #>                  ME     RMSE    MAE       MPE     MAPE MASE       ACF1 #> Training set -3.625 25.28587 22.125 -3.724331 15.88498  NaN -0.3339436 beer %>% naive() %>% residuals() -> e autoplot(e) + ggtitle("Errors from NF1 forecasts") ggAcf(e) + ggtitle("") +   labs(caption="Figure 2-7: Top: Forecast errors obtained by applying the NF1 method to the beer data.     Bottom: The ACF of the forecast errors.")

title: Using fma: worked examples
text: Sometimes adjusting data lead simpler interpretable forecasting model. section book deals three kinds adjustments. Examples given :

title: Using fma: worked examples
text: Figure 2-10 shows plot elec data set.  time plot shows size annual seasonal variation increases level series increases. variation start (towards left) 300 million kWh, recent years (right) variation exceeds 2500 kWh. mathematical transformation convenient method necessary task including increasing variation forecasts data. One possible transformation square root function. transform plotted :  can see transformation helped reducing variation seasonal cycles. make forecasting task easier un-transformed data shown Figure 2-10. number useful transformations. One common logarithm, relatively easy interpret. Section 2/7 textbook gives formulation set power transformations. plots show selection transformations.
code: elec %>%   autoplot() +   ggtitle("Australian Monthly Electricity Production") +   xlab("Year") + ylab("million kWh") +   labs(caption = "Figure 2-10: Monthly Australian electricity production from January 1956 to August 1995.        Note the increasing variation as the level of the series increases.") elec %>%   sqrt() %>%   autoplot() +   ggtitle("Square Root of Electricity Production") +   xlab("Year") + ylab("sqrt(million kWh)") cbind(     `Square root` = sqrt(elec),     `Cube root` = elec^(1/3),     `Log` = log(elec),     `Inverse` = -1/elec) %>%   autoplot(facet=TRUE) +     xlab("Year") +     ggtitle("Transformations of the electricity production data") +     labs(caption="Figure 2-11: Transformations of the electricity production data.")

title: Using fma: worked examples
text: variation time series may due variation number days (trading days) month. good idea adjust known source variation allow study interesting features. Month length can make quite impact since number days month can differ (31-28)/30 = 10%. removed, seasonal patterns become hard interpret. Section 2/7/2 textbook shows make adjustment. Figure 2-12 shows milk data set without adjusted month length. simpler pattern lead better forecasts easier identification unusual observations.
code: cbind(     Milk = milk,     `Milk per day` = milk/monthdays(milk)   ) %>%   autoplot(facet=TRUE) +   ggtitle("Monthly Milk Production per Cow") +   xlab("Months") + ylab("Pounds") +   labs(caption="Figure 2-12: Monthly milk production per cow over 14 years.     The second graph shows the data adjusted for the length of the month.")

title: Authors and Citation
text: Rob Hyndman. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Justin Carmody. Contributor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Hyndman RJ (2025). fma: Data sets "Forecasting: methods applications" Makridakis, Wheelwright & Hyndman (1998). R package version 2.5.0.9000, http://pkg.robjhyndman.com/fma/. Makridakis S, Wheelwright S, Hyndman RJ (1998). Forecasting: methods applications. John Wiley & Sons.
code: @Manual{,   title = {fma: Data sets from "Forecasting: methods and applications" by Makridakis, Wheelwright & Hyndman (1998)},   author = {Rob J Hyndman},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 2.5.0.9000},   url = {http://pkg.robjhyndman.com/fma/}, } @Book{,   title = {Forecasting: methods and applications},   author = {Spyros Makridakis and Steve Wheelwright and Rob J Hyndman},   year = {1998},   publisher = {John Wiley & Sons}, }
